data.title: Allow Extension Readmes to Show/Hide Content When Viewed in Extension Explorer or Marketplace vs on Github
data.body:
**Problem** Many extensions include heading text or logos in their README. This looks great on github but duplicates a lot of content when viewed in the vscode marketplace or in the extension explorer: ![screen shot 2017-05-13 at 12 19 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/26028493/8c8b0172-37d6-11e7-846e-e6fd36ae4559.png) ![screen shot 2017-05-13 at 12 19 35 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/26028494/90bc845a-37d6-11e7-9ef8-e80d1067fcbe.png) **Ideas** We want to avoid requiring a separate readmes but still allow different content to show based on where the extension is viewed. To support this, one thought it to allows extensions to hide this heading text when they are displayed in the editor vs on github. This could be a marker in the readme: ```markdown # My Super Extension ![](example.png) ``` or we could use classes (which would only work for html content): ```markdown

My Super Extension

![](example.png) ```

data.title: Something removes files from VSIX when being downloaded in Code
data.body:
First of all: This behavior is weird, and can't be reproduced anytime, but people(including me) had some experience with this issue.

This affected us(the team behind vscode-icons) lately more and more often, and we've got multiple people getting in touch with us because some icons were not shown. After a research, the necessary icon files weren't locally installed, but there were in the vsix uploaded, as @robertohuertasm proves. We think that the cdn managing the package-delivering stripes out some files, where the cdn thinks it is not needed **or** the vscode itself does not extract all data from the package. This started while 1.12 was in `insider`, as @JimiC says.

We suggested reinstalling the extension, this helped in some cases, but not in all.

If you have any question, do not hesitate to ask.

I'll hope you'll understand me, my English is bad.
vscode-icons/vscode-icons#924

data.title: Theming suggestion: Add option to add text-shadow color to highlighted text

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi there,

I'm the maintainer of the [Dracula theme](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=dracula-theme.theme-dracula) for vscode and I've been consistently hitting a singular annoyance: Highlighting light-colored text with a light color (as is the norm for dark themes) creates a really bad contrast situation.

Examples:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5240018/26027577/4e0530f0-37de-11e7-889b-ec5a8ab8e8d4.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5240018/26027589/662fd022-37de-11e7-88db-3924d2a10f76.png)


My suggestion is to add in the ability to give highlighted text a shadow color so that contrast can be greatly enhanced. Example: https://codepen.io/dsifford/pen/GmdYvL

Thanks for considering! üòÑ 

**Edit:** Another idea would be to automatically apply a shadow color to the text the same color as the editor background color. üëç

data.title: Context Showing Command Palette Popup
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.12.1
- OS Version:Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. When mouse click on "Indentation" in statusbar, the "Command Palette" should appear next to the clicked button.
![contextshowing-commandpalettepopup](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16800535/26025820/1d047850-37f0-11e7-95b0-85640caf9154.png)

2. The same should happen when you click on other buttons that call up the "Command Palette". Of course not all but the ones that fit. For example, from the menu> View> Command Palette, it should be old.
3. The popup with the "Command Palette" should adjust to the width of the content. It will look aesthetically.
4. It could create a new Extension API that will pop up a Command Palette contextually, with the addition of a button extension.

Thanks!

data.title: Symbol Rename does NOT rename all instances thus breaking code
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
latest 1.12.1

- OS Version:
Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In ionic2 development we typically have a view (eg. HomePage.html) and its associated "controller" eg. HomePage.ts or even perhaps an injected provider/service class eg. HomePageProvider.ts

2. When renaming in typescript code, the rename process fails to catch  angular2 embedded references to objects/props/methods,  For example if I renamed prop HomePageProvider.Users to UsersNamesList it will only update the .ts files in the project.

However, in pages as in the code below Symbol Rename fails to detect instances like **.Users** below which will require manually finding and fixing.

HomePage.html
```
<ion-list>
        <ion-item-sliding *ngFor="let level of HomePageProvider.Users">

```

I bet you those angular2 folks did not see it coming when they embedded code inside comments :)
like old SQL.

Thank you for your help and/or providing alternative solutions.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make the built-in terminal visible by pressing CTRL+`
2. Open another terminal window by pressing the + button at the top right in the terminal.

Now there will be a drop down menu to switch between terminal windows. But there should be a dedicated tab for each terminal windows for easy switch.

data.title: Add getLanguage Api to retrieve language based only on uri

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Bug**
Typescript previously used file extensions to determine which files it handles or not. This was not great because it duplicates information and also fails to account for `file.associations`.

For the upcoming work on TS server plugin work, I switched to use `openTextDocument` for this check instead. However Dirk pointed out that this brings its own problems: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/26413#issuecomment-301010494 . I don't see any ways around this using the current api, and I also don't see how we can fix the `file.associations` issue using the old file extensions based approach

**Fix**
Add a new `getLanguage` api to VSCode. This api returns the language normally associated with a resource (uri). It does not take into account any language mode that a user has explicitly changed or the first line based language detection (since the goal was to avoid opening the resource in the first place).

It's not clear to me if the current implementation based on openTextDocument will actually cause any problems. This new API may help us avoid some perf issues but also is not perfect. Let me know if you have any thoughts on a better way to achieve this

data.title: Extending the Concord debugging engine with a VS Code extension
data.body:
**Feature request**: ability to install a Concord component using a VS Code extension.

### Use case
PostSharp enhances the debugging experience by providing feature a feature named "step over aspect" or "step over interceptor", in which F11 causes the aspect/interceptor code to be skipped, so that F11 steps into business logic (e.g. most of the time people don't want to debug the caching/logging/threading logic, just the business code). Another use case is that we're fixing the "Just My Code" experience in presence of interceptors. This logic is implemented in Visual Studio using a Concord extension. The end-user documentation of these features is on http://doc.postsharp.net/debugging-runtime.

To support the same debugging experience with VS Code, we would need the ability to install a Concord add-in using a VS extension.

data.title: Not detecting language for PHP files using shebang
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: debian stretch

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open file with `#!/usr/bin/php` shebang header but not `.php` extension
2. File is not detected as PHP code, instead uses 'Plain Text' highlighter

It should be easy to fix in `vscode/extensions/php/package.json` adding a `firstLine` property, as is done for e.g. Python.

data.title: Window height not preserved across instances on second monitor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Win7 x64

Basically it looks like it decreases the height of the window so it won't cover the taskbar. Taskbar doesn't extend to the second monitor so you end up having to resize the window to fit the screen height every time you re-open.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open vscode
2. Move to second monitor
3. Increase window height so that it fills the entire height of the second monitor
4. Close and re-open vscode

data.title: Can't close tabbed header if settings editor divider directly under close X
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

This issue is a little subtle to reproduce.
Steps to Reproduce:

1.Open the settings editor (Ctrl+,).
2.Slide the divider to land just below a tabbed header close X.

![settings divider](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12818376/26019339/8f2b0164-3729-11e7-8544-ed8bc3a3db19.png)

If you try to close the tabbed header with the mouse, the hand pointer becomes the divider slider <->.
If you drag the slider in the tabbed header region, the settings editor divider moves.

The settings editor slider should never show up outside the settings editor window.

data.title: Find in Files 'Use Ignore Files' doesn't work with 'files to include'
data.body:
VSCode 1.12: I have a TypeScript project with a `src` folder and a `.gitignore` file containing this:

```
/src/**/*.js
```

If I search for something, it is OK with 'files to include' is empty:
